_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The owners, management and employees of the Valley Co-op Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local Fire Company, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



The primary activity at the facility is the storage and transfer of fertilizer for use by farmers. The maximum quantity stored would be 161,662 pounds in our 2 storage tanks(1-26,000 galllon, 1-10,000gallon).  In addition to this we have 61,166 pounds of capacity in rolling stock (14 tanks of 1000 gallon water capacity figured at 85%, which is the maximum filled capacity with NH3).  The total for this facility is 222,828 pounds.  The largest amount handled would be 41,000 pounds in the form of a delivery to our bulk plant by semi.  



The worst-case and alternate release scenarios have been removed at the request of the EPA.  This is for Security reaons and falls under the Homeland Security Act.  



 We believe that the safety culture and training our employees have been through have helped us achieve an outstanding safety record. 

  

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant proper damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



The facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA and we report all regulated materials to the Community Right to Know program, the local fire department and the County LEPC.  Several of our employees are members and officers with the local volunteer fire department.  We feel this cross training serves us well in the area of emergency preparedness.  



Our company rules do not allow employees to respond to any emergency requiring the use of a

respirator.  Employees who are trained through the fire department may leave to get the proper equipment and return as members of the fire department to mitigate the situation.  We offer free training and/or facility tours to the fire department at their convenience.  



Our employees routinely inspect the plant for necessary maintenance or improvements.  There are no upgrades or repairs needed at this time. As the state adopts more current ANSI standards, we will budget any needed improvements and they will be completed in a timely manner.  



 Our safety efforts go beyond what the rules require; we do what is good for business. Our goal is to effectively serve the community we operate in and deliver quality service to our farmer owners.
